title: Using tidyUSDA
text: need yet another “tidy” package? install many geospatial dependencies? Valid questions. work USDA data, know difficult times find need, need . sheer amount data (2017 Census Agriculture included 6.4 million points information [1]) credit USDA, huge organizational task. Currently, best way pull data previous Censuses Agriculture Agriculture Surveys Quick Stats web portal, allows apply filters interactive gui download CSV files. works great applications, R programmers hate pull data non-programmatically, tidyUSDA comes . Programmatic data pulls directly Quick Stats core, tidyUSDA API Quick Stats data, allowing pull data dataframe R session. Geospatial capabilities tidyUSDA also gives option automatically add simple features column Quick Stats data, either county national level. allows quickly visualize Quick Stats data fast iterations report generation.

title: Using tidyUSDA
text: First, install tidyUSDA instructions README section. Note may upgrade R version older build. Next, call tidyUSDA make sure everything installed correctly. USDA controls access data API keys. can quickly obtain free API key following brief instructions USDA quickstats website. Let’s pull data now. point, ’s best use actual Quick Stats website pick parameters like filter . way know sure data returned. want see state-level breakdown counts operations using 2017 census data. point helps see possible values can input function parameters. can view possible inputs parameters built-datasets. Let’s check . looks like six possible input values category field. Good know. many different geography levels. Currently support providing geometries county state values. Now ’re little clear can input, let’s use main function data pulling. Note set geometry = TRUE order include geometry feature need plotting, set lower48 = TRUE order exclude Hawaii Alaska. point, dataframe rather verbose number data fields. set geometry = TRUE, even columns. main data point Quick Stats ‘Value’ field. Feel free filter data frame fields actually need point. Now let’s see data looks like basic choropleth map.  Note: known issue RStudio graphics device macOS can extremely laggy plotting. get around , feel free use plotting methods tmap package leaflet.  Note: known issue RStudio graphics device macOS can extremely laggy plotting. get around , feel free use plotting methods tmap package leaflet. OK wow looks like farms country Texas wait second, Texas huge far landmass, relative size farms smaller balance, maybe look different way. grabbed data getQuickstat , set weighted_by_area = TRUE, creates new field ,guessed, weights main value land area county state. gives us bunch really small numbers don’t make sense, purposes mapping, ’ll .  Ahh, much better. Now true plot showing number operations per square mile.
code: library(tidyUSDA) # Use keyring to store your api key # key <- keyring::key_get("tidyusda")  # Or hard code that thing key <- '7CE0AFAD-EF7B-3761-8B8C-6AF474D6EF71'  # please get your own key! tidyUSDA::allCategory %>% head() #>             statisticcat_desc1             statisticcat_desc2  #>                "ACCESSIBILITY"    "ACCESSIBILITY, 5 YEAR AVG"  #>             statisticcat_desc3             statisticcat_desc4  #> "ACCESSIBILITY, PREVIOUS YEAR"                  "ACTIVE GINS"  #>             statisticcat_desc5             statisticcat_desc6  #>                     "ACTIVITY"         "ACTIVITY, 5 YEAR AVG" tidyUSDA::allGeogLevel %>% head() #>               agg_level_desc1               agg_level_desc2  #>       "AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT" "AMERICAN INDIAN RESERVATION"  #>               agg_level_desc3               agg_level_desc4  #>                      "COUNTY"               "INTERNATIONAL"  #>               agg_level_desc5               agg_level_desc6  #>                    "NATIONAL"        "REGION : MULTI-STATE" # Get count of operations with sales in 2017 ops.with.sales <- tidyUSDA::getQuickstat(   sector=NULL,   group=NULL,   commodity=NULL,   category=NULL,   domain='TOTAL',   county=NULL,   key = key,   program = 'CENSUS',   data_item = 'CROP TOTALS - OPERATIONS WITH SALES',   geographic_level = 'STATE',   year = '2017',   state = NULL,   geometry = TRUE,   lower48 = TRUE,    weighted_by_area = T) # Plot this data for each state tidyUSDA::plotUSDA(df = ops.with.sales) tidyUSDA::plotUSDA(df = ops.with.sales, fill_by = 'value_per_sq_mile')

title: Using tidyUSDA
text: package designed data analysts scientists, meaning output getQuickstat particularly verbose, rather cherry-picked, giving user extra data may useful. intend plot data pull getQuickstat, don’t feel like need use plotUSDA visualize results; can use method ’d like plot simple features geometry.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lindblad B (2022). tidyUSDA: Minimal Tool Set Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data Analysis Visualization. R package version 0.3.3.9000, https://bradlindblad.github.io/tidyUSDA/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {{tidyUSDA}: A Minimal Tool Set for Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data for Analysis and Visualization},   author = {Brad Lindblad},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.3.3.9000},   url = {https://bradlindblad.github.io/tidyUSDA/}, }

title:
A Minimal Tool Set for Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data for Analysis
    and Visualization
text: tidyUSDA provides R user consistent API pull USDA census survey data Quickstats. can: * getQuickstat() lets pass values fields see QuickStats website, well include simple features (SF) geometry field county state level. * View({parameter name}) lets view QuickStats available values given field (input getQuickstats(), preferably copy paste) * plotUSDA() provides quick way plot data set geometry = TRUE

title:
A Minimal Tool Set for Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data for Analysis
    and Visualization

A Minimal Tool Set for Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data for Analysis
    and Visualization
text: Depending operating system installing tidyUSDA , may need add external dependencies. Please see ‘Installation’ section sf package homepage details.

title:
A Minimal Tool Set for Gathering USDA Quick Stat Data for Analysis
    and Visualization
text: Check vignette : first need grab free API token USDA Quickstats website. last function returns ggplot choropleth:
code: vignette("using_tidyusda") library(tidyUSDA)  # Save your API token to a variable, or better yet, use the keyring package to store it securely key <- '1234-abcd'    # View all parameter names for the 'program' field View(tidyUSDA::allProgram)    # Get count of operations with sales in 2017 ops.with.sales <- tidyUSDA::getQuickstat(   sector=NULL,   group=NULL,   commodity=NULL,   category=NULL,   domain=NULL,   county=NULL,   key = key,   program = 'CENSUS',   data_item = 'CROP TOTALS - OPERATIONS WITH SALES',   geographic_level = 'COUNTY',   year = '2017',   state = NULL,   geometry = T,   lower48 = T)    # Plot this data for each state tidyUSDA::plotUSDA(df = ops.with.sales)

getQuickstat — getQuickstat
text: Get values USDA Quick Stats dataframe optional sf (simple features) geometry field

title: getQuickstat — getQuickstat
code: getQuickstat(   key = NULL,   program = NULL,   data_item = NULL,   sector = NULL,   group = NULL,   commodity = NULL,   category = NULL,   domain = NULL,   geographic_level = NULL,   state = NULL,   county = NULL,   year = NULL,   geometry = FALSE,   lower48 = FALSE,   weighted_by_area = FALSE )

title: getQuickstat — getQuickstat
text: key USDA api key. Get one https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/api - string program program field - string data_item data_item field - string sector sector field - string group group field - string commodity commodity field - string category category field - string domain domain field - string geographic_level geographic_level field - string state state field - either string character vector multiple states county county field - either string character vector multiple states year year field - string geometry geometry field (TRUE FALSE), set TRUE like simple features (SF) geometry field included. works geographic_level set 'COUNTY' 'STATE' lower48 limit data lower 48 states? - TRUE FALSE weighted_by_area option mutate new column takes target ('Value') divides square miles state county; works GEOMETRY = TRUE - TRUE FALSE

title: getQuickstat — getQuickstat
text: Go webpage https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/. best practice, select items fields test data item    exists browser using parameters function. dataset works, enter values    function parameters. Ideally, enter values key obviously, PROGRAM, DATA_ITEM, GEOGRAPHIC_LEVEL    necessary, DOMAIN, STATE, COUNTY YEAR.

title: getQuickstat — getQuickstat
code: if (FALSE) { getQuickstat(   key = "your_key",   program = "CENSUS",   data_item = "CROP TOTALS - OPERATIONS WITH SALES",   geographic_level = "COUNTY",   domain = "TOTAL",   year = "2017",   state = NULL,   geometry = T,   lower48 = T ) }
